summary: The original Broadway production of the award-winning musical that tells the story of Alexander Hamilton, first secretary of the treasury, blending hip-hop, jazz, R&B and Broadway styles, filmed from the Richard Rogers Theater in New York.

Lin-Manuel Miranda yet again stars himself as MC. Not only is a long and boring play but it is historically inaccurate. In reality Alexander Hamilton was a sweaty migrant hater. I am not joking. People who met him described him as constantly sweaty and a horrible person. In Miranda's version Hamilton like migrants which is far from the truth. Miranda is misleading illiterates who do not bother to research history for itself. Miranda on top of all of this is a sub-par lyricists who makes decent music. He's a good composer but the lyrics make me want to die. Also his overly high pitched voice for a middle aged man makes me want to take testosterone pills.

I hated this boring awful play. Lin-manuel Miranda is a bumbling narcissist who thinks he can write lyrics. (He is a half-decent composer.) He shamelessly took someone from history and twisted them. In reality Alexander Hamilton was a sweaty pig who hated migrants. Miranda takes this man and tries to make him look like a hero. He is misleading the illiterates of this world.
Overall the play itself was quite boring and cringy. I want this awful musical to fail. I hate Miranda and all of his work.
i would say this is one of the best movies ever made. but i don't consider it a movie, it is a recording of the musical. but i still do recommend it for anyone who wants to learn more about history.

Good music and excellent acting
Hamilton was very fun to watch and I would definitely recommend watching it.

This was my first time seeing this show and I know how popular it is. I like a good musical, although I suppose im somewhat less keen on theatre shows. I thought most of the songs were quite catchy and fun and the choreography is undoubtedly slick. It has a nice flow to it. I knew it was quite contemporary, in terms of the musical styles/genres used, including some rap/hip-hop (though there are numbers which are slower and less frantic) and I supppose it does give it a fresh feel, so to speak. 

I can only imagine how much energy you need to appear on stage and take part in only some of this nearly 3 hour long production. Phew. It's certainly an entertaining watch. I can't say I followed the story it tells fully but I get the general idea. I can understand why this is so popular - it definitely has a 'toe-tap' aspect to it, which is a good sign.

I wouldn't say this is entirely amazing or anything but if your a fan of musicals and this sounds of interest, then yes, I'd recommend it as a  live version of a theatrical production, rather than a film set to music as such (if you know what I mean). Its quite long at close to 2 and three quarter hours long but its certainly got a nice beat to it throughout and I thought it was pretty entertaining overall and as I say I'm not someone esp. keen on theatre. Perhaps this isn't entirely brilliant but it's certainly not boring or overly bad, hence it's worth a watch.
As good as expected and what a cast!!! Awesome!

Hamilton is a perfect example of what a musical should be. It's a very well-paced musical with the best songs of any musical. The energy of the cast blows you away, and the lyrics are meaningful. Overall, my favorite musical ever.
Genius. Absolute genius. This musical is a masterpiece. I'll leave it at that.

It's possible to argue that this isn't really a film, but it's damn hard to argue it's something other than magnificent. I'd far rather watch a very ambitious film/show/etc that tries and falls a bit short than a conservative, unambitious piece that hits all its targets. The astonishing thing about Hamilton is that not only are its ambitions sky-high, but it also hits just about all of them. Nothing new about it can really be said; it's a wonderful show and this filming does a terrific job of helping it hit home. It's a show that's tailor-made to enjoy with subtitles on, the better to catch the intelligence, wit, and artistic literacy of the songwriting. It's a treat, from start to finish.
Hamilton is definitely the best musical I've seen. Lin Manuel Miranda is a GOD at music. Especially when it comes to King George's song, "You'll be Back".

I don't know how it's possible to capture the sheer magnitude of a Broadway production (especially like this one) and make it feel as powerful and intimate as it is seeing it on Broadway but they did it. This production makes the music of Lin Manuel and it's themes all the more impactful and infectious - every detail magnified. There are so many layers to this and somehow they were able to put all of them on display. Recommended for all even if you aren't a theatre nerd.

'Hamilton' was a major surprise for me when seeing and hearing it. Music is such a big part of my life, being now a semi-professional singer and raised into a musical family, and am a fan of musicals, especially the golden age ones. History was also one of my favourite and best subjects in most of my up and down school life, until it didn't work out in sixth form when my confidence went and my comprehension and drive worsened. So having a musical to combine the two immediately intrigued me, despite not being the biggest fan of the dominant styles here (was raised on classical music and opera personally).

That is what was meant when saying that 'Hamilton' was a major surprise. Hearing that a filmed version of a production was coming to Disney+, which has been a much needed distraction, there was no doubt in my mind about seeing it. So that the mix of history and music, the meaningful and relevant lyrics, the brilliant performances and the energy and heart it has can be revisited again. It does play fast and loose with history, blame that on the musical and not the production, sure and the style(s) of music that dominates the score here are not my first choices usually, but actually for its entertainment value, emotional impact and how well crafted it is as an overall whole, 'Hamilton' was a real winner. As was this production. Which was very much needed after suffering through 'Artemis Fowl', a musical surprise adapted masterfully and so accessibly and through a particularly unsettling time in a terrible few years.

It, the production that is, looks great. The sumptuous and true to the respective periods costumes especially and the setting is not too elaborate or overblown while still never looking cheap. Personally thought that the production was very well filmed, certainly compared to other filmed productions of musical theatre, opera and ballet seen and have seen many of each (being a major fan of all three). It made me feel like a member of an audience seeing it live, expect seeing it far more accessibly in terms of money and locations. Which is what is so great about these live/streamed performances and they have proven to be invaluable. Of which 'Hamilton' has been a big highlight.

Musically, 'Hamilton' is on point. Those that don't like the styles are best staying away unless wanting to see what the hoopla is all about, but as someone that saw it with an open mind and wanting to stretch even more my musical horizons 'Hamilton' made me appreciate hip hop and rap much more because they were so well done in their own way. When they are well done and not too repetitive or preachy, yes it is dependent on how they're executed in my view rather than any bias towards the styles, that is when it is easy to appreciate them and that is what 'Hamilton' excels so well in. Also found it very well accompanied.

What also comes over brilliantly is how 'Hamilton' is written. The musical and performance are very song heavy, which some may not like dependent on what your feelings on musicals, hip hop and rap are (some love it, others hate it and it is all down to taste which is fair enough). Found the melodies very clever and easy to remember, amazing considering how many there are and not an easy thing to achieve these days. It was the lyrics though that made a bigger impression on me, these lyrics were vastly entertaining and also at times quite emotional but what is just as admirable are their honesty and how relevant they are. These are lyrics that are likely to connect for many, and from the sounds of it have done. Historically, it is far and loose but that didn't matter for me being somebody that watched not expecting a history lesson. 'Hamilton' does very well at making people more interested in history and the particular time periods depicted, that is from my experience from seeing it with people that felt exactly the same as me. What is great about this production is how it does so well in being true and capturing the spirited energy and heart of the musical itself, which is what filmed adaptations of musicals in my mind should do.

Really loved 'Hamilton's' performances. Have seen both love and hate for Lin Manuel Miranda's performance. Personally loved his work here, he was very heavily involved in making 'Hamilton' work, his dilligent efforts very much obvious here, and he gives the equivalent of the performance of his life here. He is charming and has great authority and comic timing and really do disagree that he doesn't have singing ability, he proved in 'Mary Poppins Returns' in my view that he could and he does great in this regard too. Dramatically he is the stuff of legends as is the joy that was Leslie Odom Jr. Daveed Diggs brings tremendous energy in Act 2 especially and Jonathan Groff is absolutely hilarious here. Phillipa Soo and Renee Elise Goldsberry shouldn't be overlooked either, Soo is especially good. Okieriete Onaodowan has great chemistry with Diggs and holds his own against him when they're together, especially as Madison.

Concluding, truly brilliant in my view. It won't be for all tastes but even if one is put off by the first twenty minutes if not knowing what to expect my advice really is to stick with it. It is not worth certainly not bragging about turning it off about 15 minutes or something, that is the equivalent of barely seeing it. One of the easiest 10/10's given recently.
Awesome plot, great execution, and can't stop singing the songs.

AMAZING! so good!

It's very funny and has great songs.

I saw it at the theatre and it's great to watch it again to keep the memories!

Lin Manuel Maranda did an amazing job writing this and honestly, the songs are so catchy and the set design and choreography is extraordinary.
probably the best musical ever made
It was great historical Fiction. And I especially loved the songs.

The live stage musical by Lin-Manuel Miranda is recorded with the original cast. This musical shows the life of Alexander Hamilton, one of the founding fathers of the United States of America. Some events are embellished to dramatic flair, but the basic premise of the 2004 biography of Alexander Hamilton by Ron Chernow is intact. The cast is amazing and their performances iconic. Daveed Diggs as Thomas Jefferson, Renee Elise Goldsberry as Angelica Schuyler Phillipa Soo as Eliza Hamilton and Jonathan Groff as King George III are my standouts. Miranda's music is also great with the personal favorite "Helpless". Highly recommended film, go check it out!
Worst thing I have ever seen not rap mornlike a crap never ending poem.

An American musical film about one of the primary founding fathers of America, Hamilton. The live broadway performance of actors are of highest level and the film itself is enjoyable, funny to watch and is a Work of Art.

Summary: A truly outstanding performance with a combination of song and rap, this musical by Lin Manuel Miranda is based on the true story of Alexander Hamilton, one of Founding Fathers of the United States.

Takeaways: I must admit, I was one of those people who didn't understand what all the hype was about and originally held out on Hamilton. The lyrics are phenomenal, the emotions are raw, and the sheer stamina of the performers is impressive...and this is all from a taped version of a live Broadway performance.

This filmed version of the Broadway performance wes well done.  Of course, there really isn't much need to review the blockbuster performance itself.  However, I was surprised to find the weakest performance provided by the headliner. Possibly, his performance was just over-shadowed by the otherwise stellar cast.
The fantastic cast, songs and story make this an excellent watch for everyone.

I think that this musical is very well made and the storyline is very clear to understand. I enjoyed how the concepts of trade, colonization, immigrants, the revolution were addressed in a manner where you could understand if you have not studied the history of the United States of America.

As someone who loves history and is a sucker for pop music, I adored Hamilton. The history felt mostly accurate and the creative liberties they took were in good taste. The songs range from forgettable to addicting to heartbreaking. I was surprised by the thought-provoking message the musical had. Certain characters were hilarious. Well worth the praise and popularity, although the fandom's fetishization of the characters hurts my personal view of this movie.

A top notch drama musical, but like with many plays, I tend to lose a lot of interest after the first act. It was also just less enjoyable than "In The Heights", which isn't really a fair comparison, but I had just seen that days before. I enjoy the artistic historical interpretations, but the songs sometimes dragged a bit too much for my liking. They aren't all bangers, but they were well performed.
Best musical I have ever seen in my whole life, Lin Manuel Miranda is an amazing talented man and this is a masterpiece.

lin manuel miranda never disappoints. the talent is crazy here and this play will remain relevant and in the hearts of fans that truly adore this musical

I think my favorite character had to be Eliza, she supported her husband and reacted rightly to her anger at Hamilton. The Schluyer sisters were the best thing to happen to Hamilton honestly as they preserved his legacy even though he had done well enough to be remembered in history.

Hamilton is an amazing film. It is about the life of Alexander Hamilton Lin-Manuel Miranda and Philippa Soo give excellent performances. The screenplay is well written. Thomas Kail did a great job directing this movie. I enjoyed this motion picture because of the drama and music.
I understand why people like this, but it's extremely boring and doesn't get a message across, maybe I'm just interpreting it wrong but it's a bit overrated.
My favorite musical of all time. The songs are flawless. The cast is convincing and entertaining. I loved it!

Simply fantastic! Never seen a live show before but I know you can't get these angles live. The camera angles make the show even more enticing. The creators did absolutely amazing work at putting together this story together to show the life of Alexander Hamilton, an immigrant, and how his wife, Eliza, shares his legacy after years of strife and pain. 

Alexander loses everyone and everything at such a young age and gives him this drive to become the best he can be and even better so he won't die without leaving something behind, unlike his family. The people on the island he lives on notices his intelligence and help send him to New York so he can be a new man! 

He goes to school and dreams of fighting in the war but becomes the secretary instead. Washington entrusts him with being a right hand man, but Alexander isn't satisfied and wants more. 

Alexander meets the Schuyler sisters and becomes interested in both Angelica, the oldest, and Eliza, his soon to be wife. Eliza falls in love with Alexander at first glance and, with the help of Angelica, they meet and start a romance. Eliza becomes enamored with him but Alexander is stuck on wanting to fight in the war. They send letters to each other and soon become married.

Angelica secretly loves Alexander but loves her sister more so she introduces Alex to Eliza and keeps her love for him a secret. They exchange letters because Alex feels like Angelica understands his drive to rise to the top. With each letter, Angelica wonders if Alex feels something for her. 

Alex is given the position he's been wanting and commands his soldiers in the war. It's the end of the war and he embraces his job like the soldier he wanted to be. His friends are scattered around as he leads his troop to victory as the British wave a white flag. They celebrate the end of the war and a new beginning.

Alex struggles to find his place in the new world as he studies law. People are quite overwhelmed by Hamilton's ability to not stop talking. In court, he's hard to keep quiet and his friend, Burr is irritated by it. 

As he gets older, he dabbles in politics, still Washington's right hand man. Jefferson and Madison hate Hamilton with a passion. Burr is jealous of Alex and decides to team up with Jefferson and Madison to dig up dirt on Hamilton. In the end, Alexander writes his own demise and loses the trust and respect of everyone he knows.

Let's not spoil the ending though...

I'll admit I didn't really give this much of a chance going into it. I'd heard good things about the play sure, but it's a nearly 3 hour long musical so I was coming into this with a bit of reluctance and a sigh. Sure the whole thing is a musical, which I'm not the biggest fan of, but it's more importantly some really good edutainment. Watching this made me want to learn more about the story of Alexander Hamilton because as was said(or sang I should say) he doesn't get much attention like the other Founding Fathers do. Glad I took a chance on this one, even though yes it is a bit on the long side. Well done by all who took part in this.
Super catchy, I like Lafayette and mulligan.
Hamilton is a masterpiece, a musical that use Hiphop, pop and modern music in general to give you the most amazing history class of your life.
Hamilton delivers an amazing Broadway musical masterpiece as it dazzles with a great ensemble, engaging story and amazing performances from the cast--all showcased in brilliant shots of the musical.

An important piece of theatre which transferred well to the film medium.  It inspired interest in a time in history lost to many Americans.  That... is a good thing.  Those who ignore history... as they say... are destined to repeat it.  Great show, team Hamilton!

It's not quite the same as being there obviously, and would benefit from an actual cinematic adaptation, but this is a marvelously done stage play. The originality in the storytelling is inspiring. It also features some of the best hip-hop-inspired music to come out of a musical.
The best hip-hop musical ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

So I myself have never seen a play on Broadway yet. I watched this play though. This rating is for the play itself and how it's presented on Disney+. On Disney+, the play is shown masterfully. The play is so good, it is the play we need right now because it is very feel good. I love how it has a main song throughout, yet uses other songs. It historical portrayals make interesting with all of the singing. This does not have alot of talking in it but alot of singing which is good these days. Costume design is great. The performances are so real. So, Hamilton basically lets off beautiful sparks.
This movie version is so well-shot, and the musical itself is fantastic. I don't really like musicals, but this is so catchy and captivating. Plus, history is always interesting.

This is a must-watch. I am not normally a fan of musicals, but this one, especially near the end, really worked for me. The diverse cast and the way they justify it (for a story about the founding fathers, who were all white) in a unique and meaningful way really highlights the beauty of America. I'm also glad to have learned about Alexander Hamilton, which this movie/show gave me a whole new perspective of. I won't lie, I almost cried at the end. Even if you hate musicals, at least try to check this out.
This was the first time I watched this film and it was phenomenal!! I loved all the musical numbers (or most of them). And the acting was great! I recommend this movie strongly.
The movie was disorienting and unintelligible
Doesn't work on the big screen.

Not as bad as some say, and certainty not as good as many believe. First of all, I couldn't finish it because of the endless monotony of the rapping. At times there was variety brought in by a difference in pace and rhythm, even the occasional melody surfaced, but an hour in I couldn't take it any more. It certainly had it's moments, energized and engaging, but difficult to sustain that with 2 1/2 hours of rap. I'm no fan of rap or musicals, but I gave it a shot having heard so much about the play, as well as being a history buff. I was somewhat reminded of Jesus Christ Superstar, similar in its mocking treatment of a sober subject, but the Hamilton soundtrack has nothing on the pure genious of Andrew Lloyd Webber. Some have mentioned historical inaccuracies. I didn't notice any, but I did notice important omissions. I believe the reason for the play's popularity is because of the historically turbulent times, as well as the play kind of being a dummied down, abbreviated rap version of early American history, even though I think the sesation seeking audience has little knowledge of history and more of a desire to be entertained by a percieved hip presentation aurally and visually. I noticed that when the characters emphasized minority empowerment, there were knee jerk screams in response, confirming a naieve and superficial responsec. Another major issue is that instead of characters engaing in intimate emotion (why we see stage and film plays) via dialogue, it was a constant historical narrative that just grated after awhile.
Unbelievable talent at every turn. As close to perfection as you can get.

Found it slightly hard to follow at times and consequently felt it to be slightly overlong but that's just nitpicking cause this was overall was riveting and just brilliant - incredible songs and performances!
Not really into musicals, but very glad I watched this one. Maybe I'll watch more. Leslie Odom Jr as (Aaron Burr) was amazing and Holden Ford as (King George III) was well cast.
I just can't get into this show. Part of it may be because I hate rap music. I also find it plays with history far too much (including downplaying what an ass Hamilton was in real life).
Still listening to this soundtrack. Bring more to streaming

OMG idk where to begin with how horrible this musical was. Lets ignore the incredible number of history inaccuracies for a second. I will even overlook the dellusionally misleading representation of the sort of person Alaxander Hamilton was and "values" he is characterized as having had. I was raised my whole life watching and loving musicals. This wasn't a musical. There were dancers, costumes, make-up, and audience and music but this was less of a Broadway production and more of a 4th grades classes production of American history written by the middle-aged white teacher as she attempts to show she's "hip" and "down with, like the general vibe and stuff," using hip hop. The results; a painfully simplistic, awkward, uncomfortable and condesending string of rhymes more fitting of an health class education video from the late 80's early 90's than a overpriced, Tony Award-winning Broadway Musical of the late 2010's. if the goal is to try and present the America as being more inclusive and progressive, it failed. where it succeeded is continuing the Us Vs Them mentality, only now from the viewpoint of the other side of the table. "Mr. Pot, I have Mr. Kettle on line one. I believe he mentioned something about 'black'."

A must see for any musical lover. Lin-Manuel Miranda is a different class but so are the ensemble cast who join him throughout with a heart-warming yet comedic musical that has memorable music and genius lyrics.

What a waste of time. A ridiculously goofy remake. What a sign of the times, yes let's add hip hop into the mix. Dare I say I saw a character with a Ski cap? Hamilton hits the ghetto. I can't tell if this is P.C. Or P. I. But all I have to say is P. U.

First of all, I would like to remember everyone that this is not a film it is a piece of musical theater that was filmed so that other people outside the USA could see it. And I must say that it was an amazing thing to have been done because it's an amazing piece of music. I am personally not a person fond of musicals but Hamilton is a great exception I really loved watching this piece, although it missed a bit of Alexander Hamiltons' life, namely his relationship with slavery in the USA. Nevertheless, it was an amazing musical, Lin-Manuel Miranda and the rest of the team did an amazing job and we were able to see great talent in these actors. But special attention to Lin-Manuel Miranda for making this musical possible!

I can sum Hamilton up in the following sentence.

Lin-Manuel Miranda is a genius.

But the whole show was interesting but not memorable. I can't remember any of the songs, unlike other stage performances such as "Fiddler on the Roof" or Rogers and Hammerstein musicals. Historically inaccuracies occur, but, that's know to happen with any type of production that is based on historical people or events.
Maybe seeing it live might be better?

OMG LIN MANUEL IS SO GREAT! The play is the best! I watched it on Disney+, and I am obsessed with it! I know all the lyrics to it, and the actors are amazing! I learned a lot of history, and I thought in the beginning it was about a pig XD! I would recommend to people who enjoy music!

I loved it.  I thought all the hype would lessen the power of it, but it didn't at all.  It is a good story well told.  The music is great.  I wish it was longer.   The cast is electrifying.

It is she, really, who secured  his place in history when his grand career as a revolutionary and nation-builder was cut stupidly short at the hand of a jealous rival.

DIVERSE AND CULTURAL: HAMILTON REVIEW

Look at a ten dollar bill, who is the man in the center? How can we know so little about this man on such a common bill? Hamilton is a Broadway show written by Lin Manuel Miranda, who offers a fresh perspective of one of the lesser known founding fathers and our first secretary of the treasury, Alexander Hamilton. Get ready to bob your head to American history and NO you are not too cool for Broadway because now Broadway is too cool for you! Lin Manuel Miranda uses hip hop style lyrics to tell the story of Alexander Hamilton.
      Other viewers may overlook certain themes through the show and think that its just about Alexander Hamilton's history and more of an informative show. I disagree and argue that its most important theme is to enlighten us about the importance of immigrants in U.S history. Believe it or not, Alexander Hamilton was an immigrant born in the Caribbean Islands. He is an example and inspiration to immigrants today. The song "My Shot," bags up the attitude of an immigrant. For example, the following lyrics: "When you're living on your knees, you rise up" demonstrates the reasons behind immigrating from an impoverished nation to the United States. Immigrants typically feel limited in their home countries, which is a large reason why they choose to immigrate. Another example of this is in the lyric "The plan is to fan this spark into a flame." They know that a simple spark is not enough. They need drive and determination to turn their passion into success.
       Lin Manuel Miranda illustrates the truth about hip hop. Hip hop is a form of music that most people see as  devalued but they are mistaken because is a very artistic genre of music. Hamilton is not just about boring historical accomplishments, there is rivalry, affairs, love, betrayal and much more drama! With the help of hip hop style lyrics Lin Manuel Miranda accomplishes to intrigue us into the heart of many of the character that is a cause for tears! The lyrics to Satisfied sang by Angelica, played by Renée E. Goldsberry( Schuyler sister) is an example, "But Alexander, I'll never forget the first time I saw your face I have never been the same Intelligent eyes in a hunger-pang frame And when you said "Hi, " I forgot my dang name" In other words we understand that Angelica is madly in love with Alexander but these lyrics paint how much in love she is and about what she loves about Alexander, she exaggerates forgetting her ‘dang' name rhyming with same and frame. Hip hop lyric style help us see the dynamic between two characters by figurative language and rhyme an example of this is in the song Aaron Burr, sir, "Good luck with that, you're takin' a stand You spit, I'ma sit We'll see where we land (boo)(Aaron Burr played by Leslie Odom Jr.) Burr, the revolution's imminent, to what do you stall for? If you stand for nothing Burr, what'll you fall for?(Alexander Hamilton played by Lin Manuel Miranda) this explains the different mindset and opinions that these two rivals had with each other.
     Finally, Hamilton is more than just a history lesson, but an important revelation for all viewers  about the different perspectives of things that can sometimes be overlooked like the importance of immigrants or that sometimes hip hop is more than swaying your hips to the beat. Also, Don't let this diverse and cultural Broadway show intimidate you because we learn such a shocking lesson that Hamilton is a reminder that history is still being written.

Thomas Kail's "Hamilton" is a joyous, heartfelt and spectacular stage performance that proves that Broadway musicals are worth recording live on film. With his latest feature, director Thomas Kail has crafted a breathtaking rendition of the beloved Broadway play. It's the filmmaker's first attempt to film a live recording of a beloved stage musical, but he pulls it off seamlessly. Using captivating cinematography, Kail draws viewers into the whimsical world of Hamilton. From intimate close-ups to gorgeous overhead shots, the cinematography keeps viewers immersed in the theatrical setting. The musical numbers, costumes and choreography are all carefully crafted, combining to create an immersive theatrical experience. In terms of acting, the entire ensemble is at the top of its game. Lin-Manuel Miranda delivers his finest performance to date as Alexander Hamilton. With riveting expressions, he conveys the bravery, nobility and larger-than-life nature of the iconic character. The supporting cast, which includes the scene-stealing Leslie Odom Jr., is also excellent and worthy of recognition. Although "Hamilton" is undeniably unforgettable, ultimately it is not a flawless film. At nearly three hours, it is slightly long and suffers from a lengthy running time. Nevertheless, fans of the original Broadway production will definitely enjoy "Hamilton" and so will movie-goers seeking exhilarating entertainment. At a time when Broadway remains shut down in the COVID-19 pandemic, it's a stirring reminder that beloved stage musicals are worth recording live to audiences around the world.

Watching "Hamilton" really can make you fell transported straight to Broadway, which should be enough of a testament to its power for a classical stage musical (or should I say: opera? I really feel that I should...). The show itself is full to the brim with catchy tunes and really well-thought, complicated numbers, strong humor and memorable characters as well as very impactful moments and strongly pronounced moral opinions, and the video direction manages, as it seems to me, to do to it all due justice. Although, I admit, I was at some points confused because of the fact that certain two actors (alright, it was Daveed Diggs and Okieriete Onaodowan) played here four roles in total – bad decision if you ask me (even if Diggs was killing it as Jefferson...). And this was the small problem I have with this show. The big one is that I cannot help but feel that the argumentation backing casting nearly solely non-white actors in "Hamilton" is a little sketchy – sure, it gives the show it unique character that is a large part of its success, but a the same time claims about reclaiming the story of the founding fathers for non-white community felt to me misguided and I am afraid that it can produce some dangerous conclusions...
Hamilton is Hamilton: it can do no wrong. But the recorded version cannot quite capture the same magic of seeing it live, in person.

Disney+ brings this Broadway musical about the founding father Alexander Hamilton to streaming with a recording of a live show with the original cast. And they do a very good job of keeping the live stage vibe while also taking advantage of multiple cameras with close ups and perspective changes at the right time to help enhance the emotion of a scene without overdoing it. The show is an extremely creative retelling of Hamilton's life and efforts surrounding the Revolution and the founding of our nation, almost completely told in songs that run the musical genre gambit, even including a few rap battles. And what an interesting life it was, they pack a lot in to this story but it's nicely paced. There were very few lulls, and the King George bits (which were probably my favorite) helped add a bit of levity just when you needed it. Making almost the entire cast people of color was a real power move, and there were some neat and creative technical things they did on stage like the rotating floor that helped add some extra elements of mobility. I wouldn't say I'm a huge musical person, but this was very entertaining.

I had been deliberately avoiding the soundtrack and anything else related to the show, because I wanted to see and experience it first on stage. But with the pandemic and with already having a Disney+ subscription, I sat down to watch this production. I was immediately hooked. I'm not a fan of rap music, so of course do not appreciate the nods that Lin-Manuel Miranda has expertly weaved into his amazing libretto. But I can appreciate that the amazing actors are able to enunciate the words with such clarity, yet breathtaking speed, that you can understand perfectly what is going on, even if its sometimes a feeling and an impression, rather than taking in and being able to understand the meaning  behind each and every syllable. In many ways I felt like watching Shakespeare, where I don't necessarily understand every word, but perfectly understand the intent that the author is trying to get across, through the staging and action. This is definitely a production that bears repeated watching or listening to, as I for one have picked up additional nuances each time. Since watching for the first time 
I've become semi-obsessed - listening to the soundtrack in the car, watching behind the scenes videos on YouTube, and reading the excellent Hamilton the Revolution book. Incidentally in the book and elsewhere Miranda addresses many of the criticisms levelled at his script. This is not a historically accurate documentary. It does not spend time dwelling on the fact that many of the American founding fathers were not nice people. Jefferson is criticised for the South building their wealth on the back of slave labour, but fellow slave-owner Washington is put on a pedestal. Should Miranda be criticised for the decisions to cut songs that more explicitly deal with the discussions raging even at that time over slavery, and the fragile compromises required to keep the Union together in the early days? I don't think so. Anybody dealing with 30 years of history in under 3 hours is going to have to pick which themes to concentrate on. This is just an astounding piece of entertainment and art. I'm looking forward to theatres opening up so that I can try to see it live, but capturing this performance, by this group of actors, in such a brilliant way, and then having it available at no extra charge through a streaming service I was already paying for? Thank you, thank you, thank you to everyone involved.

Let’s start by prefacing this review with how I was approaching this “film,” because I think that context is important in this case. For starters, I’m not a big fan of rap or hip-hop, and I’m pretty sure at some point in my life I made some old man statement about that stuff “not being real music.” Since I heard that most of the music in Hamilton was inspired by those genres, I was fairly confident this wouldn’t be for me, despite the fact that I typically love musicals. Then there’s the over-abundance of gushing that people have done about the show and its music for 5 years, including a huge uptick in conversation months before this release. I heard stories of people willing to pay tens of thousands of dollars for tickets, and still struggling to get a seat. With that kind of hype it’s inevitable that the actual production can’t possibly live up to expectations. Friends of mine had even found their way to a touring version of the show, and told me they felt ripped off for having paid that kind of money for the show they got. At this point, I had pre-determined in my head that this movie would be overrated, and I was loading up both barrels to unleash a storm of hate on it. Admittedly, I was paying nothing to watch it (thanks to Disney+,) but I still expected disappointment. When I began watching this filmed version of the Broadway musical, I was fairly confident all my trepidation was warranted. The opening number was spitting rhymes at me with such speed and in a rhythm that I could not comprehend more than a handful of words. I was struggling not only to understand the specific lyrics they were rapping, but also to get the overall point of them. (I know, my old age is really showing now.) As a result, less than 5 minutes into the show, I rewound to the beginning and turned on the closed-captions. This definitely helped me to follow the story, even though I still wasn’t particularly fond of that opening number. But this is where I admit...from there on, the musical won me over. I found myself smiling and enjoying parts of the show, and I even hummed along with some of the tunes when they hit a familiar refrain. I was having a good time, and said out loud “Uh oh, this is actually good.” It does help that the entire film is not rap or hip-hop. In fact, the bulk of it plays more like a traditional Broadway musical, and I’m a sucker for big numbers like these. They even include some of those brilliant layered songs where they merge a few of the different character songs into one big bombastic number. There are still elements that I don’t love about Hamilton. I don’t particularly enjoy when a story tells you how it will end at the beginning. Even if these things are common knowledge because it’s a historical film, I don’t love when someone just spells out the conclusion in the first minutes of the movie. I’m also not a fan of biopics that detail such massive periods of time. I’ve always preferred when a movie focuses on a more specific event and creates an entire arc that way, rather than showing the full life of the protagonist. Because of this, I often felt like Hamilton was rushing, and the plot wasn’t given enough time to breathe in any one moment in history. I sometimes struggled to see the importance of certain events and wondered why some subplots were included at all. It’s also interesting that I didn’t particularly love Alexander Hamilton as a character. He was somewhat unpleasant and abrasive, and frankly Lin-Manuel Miranda was far from the best actor/singer on stage. Despite the difficulties I had with the show, I still have some of the melodies stuck in my head days after watching it. My expectations were that I would hate this specially-filmed version of the stage musical, and I was pleasantly surprised. In fact, I’ll probably watch Hamilton again.

After watching Hamilton, I realized I had misused the word Masterpiece all my life. I used to think that I was surrounded by new  masterpieces in music, movies and Videogames. I compared the quality of those things I read and saw to what I had been taught were the masterpieces of our past. If a particular things achieved parity with the past it is a masterpiece. Now I know that a masterpiece pushes an era forward. It creates a schism, with the past and redefines something.

Hamilton has it's flaws and history will judge it fiercely, in a good way and on a bad way, but with fierceness but it is and will always be an era defining masterpiece.

A historically affectionate piece of writing that brings up new controversies and debates about the origins of old U.S. through the eyes of the rather flawed but eager, ambitious but destructive ten dollar Founding Father. If a bit long winded, structurally, Lin-Manuel Miranda’s musical lyricism succeeds in connecting the known present with the forgotten past, tightly weaving musical motifs across the entire viewing and sending out a universal message of how one can either confirm their own legacy or damn it all to hell with one choice. The company of Hamilton brings the libretto to life in weird but rather effective choreography and in sound tone. Finally, the main Original Broadway Cast of Hamilton, with props to Miranda, Leslie Odom Jr., Daveed Diggs, Reneé Elise Goldsberry, Christopher Jackson, Jasmine Cephas Jones, Anthony Ramos, Okieriete Onaodowan, Jonathan Groff, and Philippa Soo, are matches made only in dreams as they transcend in singing across the stage and envelope into these characters that may or may not be what history makes them out to be.

Superb musical wonderfully presented on Disney +, making for the next best experience after seeing it in person.  The cast is superb across the board, with the scene stealers being Phillpa Soo as Eliza Hamiliton, Alexander's loving but suffering wife, and Jonathan Groff as King George.  Behind the stage, Lin Miranda Emmanual crafts a brilliant musical with catchy songs while also staying fairly close to history, covering Alexander Hamilton's impoverished background, brilliance, adultery and ultimate death at the hands of Aaron Burr (a brilliant Leslie Odom Jr.).  The multi-racial cast is a brilliant touch, as it ultimately shows the founding fathers belonged to all Americans, no matter their race, while also nailing their personalities for modern audiences.  If you have Disney +, this is a must watch, and if you don't, this is a reason to get it.

This is a filmed recording of the hit musical Hamilton, a musical about first Secretary of the Treasury Alexander Hamilton featuring a predominantly Hispanic and African American cast and hip-hop music mixed with other styles. From what I understand, it mixes footage from a live performance and separately filmed close-ups. This is a wonderful show!

The story in this is an engrossing look at one man's life and death, his tremendous highs and lows. Besides being dramatic, the clever lines in this can also be pretty funny.

The songs in this are truly unique. This presentation shows why Hamilton is the biggest musical of the decade. It accomplishes something that appears to be rarer and rarer in recent decades: every song is a winner. This is especially impressive since this is a song-only musical with basically no spoken dialogue.

The one part of this show that could be an issue for some is that singing and exposition can go by pretty quickly, especially in the first fifteen minutes, and you could miss something.

The choreography and staging are also great, not to mention very creative at times. The dancing really accentuates the story and songs. The set rather than changing scenes takes the minimalist route of having one basic set and the use of body movement, props, and a couple other stage aspects in order to tell the story. It's all so complex and fascinating to watch.

The performances in this are top-notch all-around. I've heard and seen a lot of comments that Lin Manuel-Miranda (the lead and creator of this) isn't as strong a singer as the rest of the cast, however it's hard to imagine anyone else in the role. (Though by now, I'm sure plenty of people on stage have.) He just pulls off the man's drive so well in such a passionate manner. Going back to the show's sense of humor and unique interpretations, we are treated to a couple of delightfully flamboyant turns from Daveed Diggs and Johnathan Groff (from Frozen and Mindhunters).

The nice thing about this compared to seeing the show live on stage is that the close-up shots allow you to truly get a good look at the actors' expressions. (Though once in a while since the blocking is done in relation to talking in the direction of an audience, the actors can be facing the camera at an odd angle. It's not a big issue.)

Overall, I can not recommend this tremendous work enough.

It's about vision.
It's about Alexander Hamilton's vision. It's about Eliza Hamilton's vision.
It's about "Alexander Hamilton" author Ron Chernow's vision.
It's about Lin-Manuel Miranda's vision of the Broadway play Hamilton.

And it's about the vision you take with you after witnessing Hamilton.
Not all the visions are the same. And that's the essential point of Hamilton.
It's the point of what America is all about. That's never changed.
This musical is a must see! You may need a good surround sound system to really enjoy it.

Lin-Manuel is a fan of the same things I am. "Weird Al," The Adventure Zone, Howard Ashman and Alan Menken. It should come as no surprise he also finds great pleasure in the stories in the past.  In "Hamilton," Lin tells the story of the least discussed dead white guy on our money. While it's impossible to give the full scope in a theatrical performance, I believe this is an amazing portrait of the man, his life, and his impact on history, which is miracle enough, but that's not all the play accomplishes. This hip hopera of historical proportions is one moment after another of moving depth, thought-provoking insight, and winking levity that come together in explorations of the trials of ambition, what it really means to be an American, and the sacrifices required if you want to be remembered by history.
Thank you for bringing the experience to our homes! Amazing 👏 inspiring

Pumped full of infectious music, incredible wit, surprising humor, and an engaging narrative, Hamilton is the defining musical of a generation for a reason. Presenting the production in this format, essentially a conventional rendition of the stage play with some well-designed camerawork, asks an interesting question regarding potential depictions of Broadway hits in film. The deluge of classic stage adaptations that essentially simply design conventional sets but replicate the dialogue and music word-for-word now look to be something of a Hollywood cash-in on the intellectual property of others, even lesser than consistent franchise sequels as they require precisely zero creativity. Presenting Hamilton in its original configuration does not infringe on its impact and requires not an ounce of producer intervention, and the results speak for themselves. I'm not sure it can be effectively counted as a film instead of a recording in another medium, at best it's a hybrid of the two. Will we see more of this format in the future? I hope so. (4.5/5)

Today marks the 22nd consecutive day I’ve watched part or all of the show. Need I say more?

Multi-hyphenate sensation Lin-Manuel Miranda's Hamilton sounds like a bizarre misfire, a hip-hop-infused musical about one of the lesser known Founding Fathers, and yet not only does it succeed so magnificently, so transcendentally, it's one of those rare artistic pinnacles that lives up to its own momentous hype. This is one of the crowning artistic achievements of the twenty-first century. I'm exceedingly grateful for a filmed version of the vaulted stage experience, with the original cast, that allows me that front-row view my bank account never would afford. This is going to be a film review of what is, essentially, a live theatrical performance, but really this written review is going to be a celebration of Hamilton and what I consider to be so phenomenal.

In 1776, Alexander Hamilton (Miranda) is an immigrant to looking to make his name in the American colonies and the looming war with Britain for independence from King George III (Jonathan Groff). He meets and befriends Aaron Burr (Leslie Odom Jr.), an ambitious upstart who seems fatefully linked with Hamilton through the decades. Hamilton falls in love and marries Eliza Schuyler (Phillipa Soo) but also has a close relationship with her older sister, Angelica (Renee Elise Goldsberry), who keeps her real feelings at bay to protect her sister. Eager to get into the action, Hamilton accepts a position as George Washington's (Chris Jackson) right-hand man as the battle comes to New York and the colonists do the unthinkable and defeat England as we conclude the musical's first act. "You'll be back," King George retorts.

Next comes the tricky part of building a functioning country in the aftermath. Hamilton is appointed to be Secretary of the Treasury by newly elected President Washington, but his federalist principles are fought against by some pretty big names in the cabinet, like James Madison (Okieriete Onaodowan) and Secretary of State, Thomas Jefferson (Daveed Diggs). Both are wary of a centralized government and prefer more power to be held by the states. The Founding Fathers jostle for ideological supremacy and Hamilton gifts his opponents with the burgeoning nation's first political sex scandal with Maria Reynolds (Jasmine Cephas Jones). Aaron Burr rises in local and national politics but sees Hamilton as a constant thorn in his side. With the presidential election so close in 1800, Hamilton's endorsement of Jefferson over Burr is the final straw, and Burr demands satisfaction in a duel against Hamilton that will prove tragic.

For fans of musical theater, Hamilton is a two-hour-forty-minute joyously exuberant celebration of a bold artistic vision, the electricity of live theater, and broadening American history in a manner that makes it far more accessible, relevant, and humane for a modern audience. The very nature of having minority actors portraying the Founding Fathers and their famous wives is part of Miranda's appeal that he wanted to tell the story of America with the America of today. Ordinarily, African-Americans would never get an opportunity to play Washington or Jefferson, or a Chinese-American woman playing the role of Eliza Hamilton, and there is definite power in representation, in seeing these different faces playing these historical figures. The deliberate color-blind casting makes America's history feel more inclusive. It's such a simple act, opening the ethnicity of historical roles, but it produces a beautiful result and provides even more cross-textual commentary, like slave-owning presidents played by black thespians.

Another miraculous effort by Miranda is his ability to generously humanize many of the characters, including the man who eventually murders Hamilton himself. Very often when we talk about the Founding Fathers and other Great Figures of History from oh so long ago, they take on a mythic quality and seem less human, less flawed, and less relatable. They seem practically superhuman, absent our doubts and desires. Miranda's portrayal of the men and women of America's founding does the opposite and makes these people feel relatable, flawed, and human yet again.

This includes Hamilton as well. He's obsessed with his sense of legacy, has a pretty healthy ego that gets him into trouble, and might have been having an emotional affair with his sister-in-law, never mind an actual affair with Maria Reynolds. He's so concerned about his "good name" and rumor of impropriety (he was accused of embezzling government money to pay for Ms. Reynolds' husband's extortion) that he literally confessed to his marital misdeeds and published it. Hamilton is consumed with writing his ideas ("Why do you write like you're running out of time?") and an impending early death, something he amazingly escaped during a hurricane in the Caribbean that destroyed his village as well as his mother's fatal illness. He was so eager to get into the heat of war that Washington had to sit him down to persuade him that dying as a martyr isn't as glamorous as living and seeing through your ideals. Hamilton's death at the hands of Burr is likely the most widely known fact about both duelists, but the musical brings each to glorious and troubled life with unerring compassion without excusing their real failings.

Burr serves as the narrator of our near three hours, setting the stage for Hamilton's story with his own regrets and jealousies framing his recounting. He's a complex character worthy of his own biopic, an orphan who finished college in two years, had an affair with the wife or a British officer, lost her at sea, and championed retail politics centuries before it was the norm. His personal philosophy was one of caution, diametrically opposed to Hamilton jumping after whatever he wanted no matter the consequences. Burr longs for being near the real center of power, and his showstopping number "The Room Where It Happens" is an ode to his desire. He begins as a friend and ally of Hamilton, then political rival, and finally as a mortal enemy. He's too calculated with his personal beliefs, never wanting to be too challenging and at risk, which is an embodiment of his social-climbing ambition as well as his callow decision-making. To Burr, avoiding risk and not accruing enemies is simply smart business. The musical does an excellent job of humanizing Burr ("Now I'm the villain in your history book") and offering a perspective in opposition to Hamilton but not without its own measurable merits.

The domestic side of Hamilton could be its own movie to itself. The relationship between Alexander, Eliza, and Angelica is complicated to say the least. Angelica was the elder sister and in her stellar song "Satisfied" she details the social pressures of being in that position, being expected to marry into a desirable match that will see the family name and fortune to prosper. Feeling initially unsure about Hamilton's intentions, she introduces him to her sister Eliza instead, and it's a choice that she feels conflicted about ever since. Angelica dearly loves her sister ("I love my sister more than anything in this life/ I will choose her happiness over mine every time") but cannot help but still feel a yearning for her brother-in-law. However, when the Reynolds scandal comes to light, she will defend her sister to her dying breath. That sisterly deference makes Angelica such a fascinating figure, and it certainly makes the Hamilton marriage more intriguing and roiling with pent-up desires. Eliza sings about removing herself from the narrative in "Burn" and how her husband has "forfeited the rights to my heart." She's been trying to impress upon her husband to be happy in the moment ("Look around, look around/ How lucky we are to be alive right now") and enjoy his accomplishments rather than looking ahead. Her eventual forgiveness of Hamilton is one of the most emotional moments of the show that causes me to tear up. And she serves as a final testament to Hamilton's legacy during the final number, after his death, and fills in the gaps of history by asserting her own agency back into the observed "narrative."

I've gone over 1300 words, dear reader, and I haven't even talked in depth about the music, so allow me to say that Hamilton as a musical is just about music perfection. Hip-hop is such a densely wordy platform that allows so much information to be imparted at lightning speed, which means that lyrically these songs are jam-packed with clever asides, allusions, and rhyming recitations of history. The songs are instantly quotable and filled with deep consideration from witticisms to also important dramatic themes and perspectives. I was amazed at Miranda's composition skills in particular how he's able to weave and build off character leitmotifs. It's brilliant how something like Hamilton's declarative early song "Not throwing away my shot" about his ambitions can come back during his duel with Burr where he raises his pistol in the air, away from Burr, and literally throws away his shot. Or how the beat of a song can imitate a failing heartbeat in a fractious moment of tragedy. Or how King George's self-involved songs are fashioned to be like 1960s British invasion pop ditties. Or how cabinet arguments become riotous battle raps between Jefferson and Hamilton. Or how the same actors who played Hamilton's wartime buddies in Act 1 are playing his political rivals in Act 2 ("Have you forgotten Lafayette?" he asks of Jefferson, the same man who portrayed Lafayette). There are layers and layers to the compositions here and the music is remarkably assured; almost every song is a certified earworm, and it's an entirely sung musical. Every person will have their favorites, and for me they include "Satisfied," "The Room Where It Happens," "History Has Its Eyes on You," "Dear Theodosia," "One Last Time," and the moving finisher, "Who Lives, Who Dies, Who Tells Your Story." Even if you don't like rap music, Miranda's offerings are so catchy, so accomplished, and so bursting with excitement, that it's near impossible to resist.

This movie was filmed in 2016 from the original Broadway cast, many of whom earned Tony awards for their sensational work (Diggs, Goldsberry, and Odom Jr.). Everyone is truly excellent but my favorite performer, by far, is Diggs (Blindspotting). He gets to spit lightning-fast rhymes in a French accent as Lafayette, and his portrayal of Jefferson as a dandy in the style of Andre 3000 from Outkast is enormously entertaining. His "What Did I Miss?" introductory number is a perfect impression for Jefferson's arrival onto the stage. Diggs' is so charming even when he's being a scoundrel trying to plot the doom of Hamilton. His battle raps with Miranda are a highlight and Diggs also seems to get the most tricky lyrical arrangements because of his peerless skills at maintaining flow and diction ("I'm in the cabinet, I am complicit in/ Watching him grabbin' at power and kiss it/ If Washington isn't gon' listen/ To disciplined dissidents, this is the difference./ This kid is out!"). There's a reason Diggs has become the other breakout star of the show.

Soo (The Code) breaks my heart with her Act 2 solo numbers and then mends it back as she reasserts herself on "Who Live, Who Dies, Who Tells Your Story." Goldsberry (Altered Carbon) has such a fire to her. Groff (Mindhunter) is hilarious as King George, though his singing involves a lot of literal spitting. Miranda (Mary Poppins Returns) is exceptional as the titular character who comes from nothing and through the power of his ideas creates America's financial institutions that are still standing to this day. But it's his personal relationships that better define him in the play. The fatherly relationship he has with Washington is affectionate ("One Last Time" has an extra poignancy knowing Washington died shortly after leaving office) and his hopes for his newborn son ("You'll Blow Us All Away") speak to a larger truth about parenting that also links up with the foundation of a nation in infancy. There's also his complicated love divided between Eliza and her sister. Miranda has such a natural charm and swagger and earnestness that seeps into his performance and every performer.

So is there anything about this movie-wise to separate it from a bootleg of the show? Director Thomas Kail (also the director of the musical) does make smart use of when to go tighter on his actors, to zero in on the emotions and expressiveness, and when to go wider for best impact. The stage is designed like a bullseye with a rotating circle, which can play up the dramatic confrontations between foes, especially the duels. I was impressed at points where the movement of the stage would be perfectly timed with camera focus and edits, allowing other characters to loom over the shoulder, or pop into focus, giving the production a greater sense of filmed visuals. However, this is really a filmed version of the stage show, so as a movie, it's only going to do so much with those trappings. The unreality of theater has to be accepted but the movie version does a great job of maintaining the intimacy of the shared theatrical experience. It's even nice to hear the applause after the musical numbers or some of the laugh lines hit home.

By this time, you've likely heard about the Broadway-smashing Hamilton success story of Miranda and his crew but do yourself a real favor and watch the movie with the OG cast. Yes, there are historical shortcuts taken for dramatic license and not everything you see on stage will be one hundred percent accurate with the long record of history, but it all clicks for the greater storytelling aims. Some might be uncomfortable with the re-visioning of the Founding Fathers, either by the open-ethnicity casting or glossing over their slave-owning faults, but Miranda's larger goal of making history reflective of the people who currently live today is admirable. In short, unless you have the kind of money to blow on a front-row ticket, enjoy the Hamilton movie experience until Miranda eventually wrangles his artistic milestone into a more movie-movie version.

Hamilton (2020) review, Rotten Tomatoes 🍅 
How was the Broadway show so perfectly captured? In every nuance: close ups, dance moves, even angles never seen by any audience, how is it ever smooth, cohesive and crystal clear? The answer: director Thomas Kail, who is experienced in television and film as well as theatre, and who directed both Hamilton and Lin Manuel Miranda's previous Broadway hit, In the Heights. Kail intimately understands how to glean the best essential Hamilton. The performers all had a year of live shows under their belts, therefore this is one of the most thoroughly rehearsed films yet is spot on energy wise. The ensemble work is very strong. The Greek chorus are present almost always, acting all background and minor roles, switching character constantly with the precision of Andy Blackenbuehler's choreographed dance language. Clearly every character is integral and motivated from the lead to the bullet (yes, one of the chorus is briefly the bullet that kills Hamilton); every cast member and every dance move support lyrics, story and action. The production is visually striking, lighting and design also support the story yet reflect the period. The clothes are exquisite. The writing is cerebral, profound hilarious, emotional and timely. The voices blend beautifully and are lovely individually. The quality of singing is top notch, all of it. Principals Leslie Odom Jr, Daveed Diggs, Christopher Jackson, and Renee Elise Goldsberry and Philippe Soo are powerful and evocative. Anthony Ramos is convincingly Hamilton's closest friend and as his son seems actually to have de-aged to a boy of 9. Jasmine Cephas Jones has the sultry chops to carry the femme fatale Mrs Reynolds. Lin Manuel Miranda's emotion has me in tears at numerous points; with love and grief he shares with wife Eliza, and what here in Ireland we call the grá, or yearning fondness and matched wit he shares with her sister Angelica. And then there's the music! (You've probably heard?) Its stunning. 
Best of filmed musicals, best of cocooning remedies.
PS Watch out for one of the chorus, Ariana DeBose, who will play Anita in Spielberg's forthcoming West Side Story.

One of the best shows to ever be performed on Broadway.

You can finally see the musical performed on Broadway, for the reasonable fee of $7.00. If you have never seen or heard Hamilton, check this out. It is your chance to fall in love with the musical, and join a new Fandom full of awesome people if you like it! Who knows? If you haven't heard of "Hamilton," you're likely living under a rock. This play is all anyone can talk about for the last few years and I was eager to see what the hype was about. I can honestly say the hype is well deserved for this musical. I liked the decision to simply record the stage production because watching this felt like I had a front-row seat on Broadway. This is a hugely original show with outstanding music and tons of memorable songs. Almost every song in this musical has an irresistible and infectious energy to it. It's no surprise this show launched a lot of the people involved to even bigger stardom and was such a cultural phenomenon. I would say if you haven't seen the show live or didn't take time to actively listen to the soundtrack, like myself, you should definitely check this out.

With Hamilton, Lin Manuel-Miranda completely changed the face of musical theatre. So when I heard Disney+ were developing a movie adaptation, it's fair to say that I was slightly apprehensive, wondering how well it would capture the magic of sitting in the theatre, watching the story unfold. 

However, I'm delighted to report that this movie worked exceptionally well. Not only does it embrace being filmed, but the direction by Thomas Kail and cinematography by Declan Quinn is breathtaking and adds a whole new dimension to the beloved musical. 

If you're a Hamilton connoisseur, you'll get to experience this groundbreaking musical from an all-new angle. If you are new to the tale, apart from being at a live show, there is absolutely no better way to get the greatest Hamilton experience!
Exceeded my expectations! As someone who's seen this live, I can honestly say that this is just as good. A MUST-WATCH for everyone!
I saw the stage version originally and thought there was no way a movie could replicate the stages beauty but it absolutely did.

Except for missing the energy from a live audience, this is perfection!  My cat was not as excited as I was but I finally got to see all of the parts I missed the 3 times I saw it live.  The detail was amazing and so up close and personal.  I cried, I laughed and really enjoyed the original cast at their best.  Lin looked a bit tired in a few scenes but I learned they filmed this is 3 days and every waking moment was spent getting the close ups and everything perfect, which they did!  I have listened to the Original Cast sound track so many times and it was fantastic to see who were behind those voices.  I was really impressed with Anthony Ramos performance and was surprised how many scenes he seemed to steal.  I knew Daveed Diggs killed his 2 parts and of course Lin and the rest of the cast but his voice and acting ability stunned me.  Thank you Lin and of course Disney for releasing this early, there is so much to learn from this and I believe it is a movie that will go down in American history for centuries.  I am waiting for the sequel....perhaps Washington or Franklin??  I truly believe this is the greatest piece of art I have ever seen and will never forget it.  There are a lot of words, and sometimes they can be spoken very quickly, every time I see it I hear and learn something new.  Enjoy!
